answers.body:
You can run multiple scripts by the && operator. For example:

{
  "scripts": {
    "lint": "eslint",
    "test": "jest",
    "ci-test": "npm run lint && npm run test",
  }
}

npm run ci-test will execute the lint and test script.

Nested scripts like in your example are not supported.

But you could do the following:

{
  "scripts": {
    "sample": "run --spec '*spec.js'",
    "CB.Test1": "Test one com",
    "CB.Test2": "Test two com"
  }
}

So you can call for example npm run CB.Test1.

See docs.
Objects/Arrays are not supported for scripts. You have to go with a String. Which means you'll have to go with adding line by line.

I don't think you can do this, but you should break two commands like that under scripts tags. There can be two ways to want to run theses commands : concurrently or sequentially based on the requirement.

If you want to run them concurrenly make these changes first to the package.json:

npm i --save concurrently

"scripts": {
    "sample": "run --spec '*spec.js'",
    "CB":{ "concurrently \"command1 arg\" \"command2 arg\""}
  },

npm run CB

If the second script is based on the first and want to run sequentially using run-s, you can do something like this:

"scripts": {
    "sample": "run --spec '*spec.js'",
      "Test1": "Test one com",
      "Test2": "Test two com"
  },

run-s Test1 Test2

You can check there documentation here: Concurrently and npm-run-all.

title: Add and execute set of scripts to package.json
body:
I'm new to Node.js, and I need to add a set of scripts to package.json and execute one by one, as explain below. May I need to know is it possible with Node.js?

"scripts": {
    "sample": "run --spec '*spec.js'",
    "CB":{
      "Test1": "Test one com",
      "Test2": "Test two com"
    }
  },

I can execute the "sample" command using "npm run sample."

My Question how to run "Test1"? And is it possible?
